job_title: Customer Service Assistant in Birmingham, England
pros:
Sense did provide a good amount of overtime to the CSA team before it was disbanded.

The dual role of covering in the Hive Cafe and working reception was an interesting experience however the reception part of the job was quite redundant at times, mainly needed because of the strange policy of having barriers for a customer car park.

Many of the volunteers are lovely people who have true potential in life and just need to realise it.
cons:
Management is very peculiar indeed, they expect a lot from staff but do not put much work in themselves. They have grand ideas because they see themselves as important visionaries but these ideas do not take into account the realities of real life.

Very unorganised place, not much communication between teams that work within the same building. 

Very clique based and not professional in any manner, many of the staff that are management are quite strange people who are laid back in their positions. Quite a lot of management 'work from home' and are holier than thou because they work for a charity.

You have to deal with stereotypically middle-class individuals who want their decaff oat milk latte with seahorse dreams and the sandwich must be gluten-free and vegan or whatever is the fad of the month. These customers also include many stay at home mums who talk about the meaning of motherhood while their kids play in the street.

pros: Good location in London, nice open plan office can't really think of anything else!
cons: Sickly organisation, strange quite aggressive negative culture exists particularly within fundraising, cross team working does not exist, silo's and concrete walls are everywhere, there is no creativity or dynamism, going through yet another restructure. So many staff are now interim, and people are threatened by change makers who are trying to make things better for the long term. A few teams and individuals go above and beyond and are swamped with work whilst the rest sit back and coast.

pros: Sense is a  company that cares about the people it serves.  Job security is safe and good annual and sick  leave.
cons: No bank holiday  pay or extra night pay.  Pay is low-middle for the responsibility, therefore losing the ideal candidates for the position and employing less motivated and qualified personnel.

pros: sense was a truly great atmosphere to work in where co-workers were real friends. work was not that hard and as an volunteer employee you are able to purchase items in the shop at discounted prices.
cons: at times on certain days it was quite boring with few customers if you worked only on the shop floor but there was also something to do in the back stock.

pros: The people they support are awesome
cons: The money is poor, but to be honest if you do this sort of work the money is not the reason for doing it. The management are bullies, dishonest and only interested in what the public think of the organisation. Person centred approach? That's a joke.... It's whatever serves the organisation better....... I was threatened and bulked while working for sense, so glad I got out when I did.... I miss the people I supported, and really hope sense is "outed" for the way it really treats its staff and the people they support

review_title: Uninspiring, overworked, unappreciated and no room for growth.
pros: The only positives of the workplace are working with those you support, and the staff who work as a team amongst you.
cons:
Management and team leaders are clueless, lacking people skills and any knowledge of running a day centre. Their main priorities are ticking boxes for HR, and money. "Do as I say, not as I do". That's the attitude you get, they do as they please and do not lead by example. And if you dare speak out, prepare to be repremanded. And they do stick together. If you ever have a concern or issue with management, a 'seperate' centre manager will intervene. Unfortunately. So whatever you say can be nipped in the bud, shoved under the carpet and forgotten. Next thing you know they'll return to their cuppa and a smoking break together.

The experience of myself and others is that we are constantly and consistently understaffed, overworked and pushed to our absolute limits. The dedicated and hardworking unfortunately not valued, thus a skeleton of staff remain.
Receiving rotas three days before they start, rotas being changed without informing those they affect, staff being pushed to sickness, and witnessing extreme bullying in the workplace. 

The hardest parts for me were;
1. Having to explain to parents and guardians why those we support spend everyday inside the centre with hardly any staff. 
2. Watching important safeguarding matters being pushed to the side and having to do my absolute best in quite frankly diabolical conditions.
3. Being classed as experts in helping those with complex disabilities and those who are deafblind. As well as a charity with plenty of multisensory technology and knowledge, and helping people fill their potential. The resources are sparse, dated and far from what they advertise. And sadly, a lot of time is spent sitting. 
4. I always stuck to my own standards, as a dedicated and hardworking team member. And I did try my hardest to make management happy, but there was no appreciation for staff. You were very lucky to receive a thank you. Throughout my time I remained hardworking, doing my best for individuals I supported and for the team. I worked my socks off at times but there wasn't any acknowledgement of that. The only people that cared were my fellow team members. And they often said I was too good for the place. A thank you would have meant a lot. 
5. Those who want to grow and flourish in the company are not encouraged or wanted. British Sign Language is no longer something they are interested in you studying and care qualifications are not of management's interests. It would have been brilliant to have felt valued, wanted and workplace growth to have been encouraged. But they made sure I understood that I had my place and that was adequate enough.

And  lastly, the 'I Statements'? Well you won't be listened to, respect doesn't exist and there's plenty of decisions made about you without you.

Do not rely on the reputation that the name of the company perceives.
